sen.j: 天つ罪・国つ罪（あまつつみ・くにつつみ）とは、神道における罪の観念である。
sen.e: "Amatsu tsumi" and "Kunitsu tsumi" are the concepts of crime in in the Shintoism.
"Amatsu tsumi" and "Kunitsu tsumi" are concepts of crime in in the Shintoism.
"Amatsu tsumi" and "Kunitsu tsumi" are concepts of crime in in the Shintoism.

sen.j: 『延喜式』巻八「祝詞」に収録される大祓詞に対句として登場する。
sen.e: These terms occur as a pair in oharae no kotoba (the great purification incantation) described in "Norito" (incantations) in Fascicle (Book) 8 of the "Engishiki" (an ancient book for codes and procedures on national rites and prayers).

These terms occur as a pair in oharae no kotoba (the great purification incantation) described in "Norito" (incantations) in Fascicle (Book) 8 of the "Engishiki" (an ancient book for codes and procedures on national rites and prayers).

sen.cmt: 原文の「」に合せて"を'に訂正しました。余分なスペース削除しました。

sen.j: 天津罪・国津罪とも書く。
sen.e: Amatsu tsumi and Kunitsu tsumi are written in Kanji characters as "天つ罪" and "国つ罪" or "天津罪" and "国津罪."
sen.cmt: 漢字表記の説明のため漢字を残しました。
sen.e: Amatsu tsumi and Kunitsu tsumi are written in Kanji characters as "天つ罪" and "国つ罪" or "天津罪" and "国津罪."
Amatsu tsumi and Kunitsu tsumi are written in Kanji characters as "天つ罪" and "国つ罪" or "天津罪" and "国津罪."

sen.j: 天つ罪・国つ罪は、宗教と政治と法制が密接であった古代日本における「罪」に対する考え方を窺い知るのに重要である。
sen.e: Amatsu tsumi and Kunitsu tsumi are important concepts to understand the view of "crimes" in ancient Japan, where religion, politics, and legislation were closely related.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Amatsu tsumi and Kunitsu tsumi are important concepts in understanding the view of "crimes" in ancient Japan, where religion, politics, and legislation were closely related.
Amatsu tsumi and Kunitsu tsumi are important concepts in understanding the view of "crimes" in ancient Japan, where religion, politics, and legislation were closely related.

sen.j: しかし、本居宣長以来指摘されているように天つ罪・国つ罪は宗教的に関わりの深い「罪」を挙げたものである。
sen.e: As Norinaga MOTOORI and the successors pointed out, however, Amatsu tsumi and Kunitsu tsumi were the crimes that were closely related to religion.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: As Norinaga MOTOORI and the successors pointed out, however, Amatsu tsumi and Kunitsu tsumi were crimes that were closely related to religion.
As Norinaga MOTOORI and the successors pointed out, however, Amatsu tsumi and Kunitsu tsumi were crimes that were closely related to religion.

sen.j: これらに属しない世俗的な「罪」が存在していた事は『古事記』・『日本書紀』の中にも記されている。
sen.e: "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters) and "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan) include descriptions implying that the secular crimes also existed in ancient Japan.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters) and "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan) include descriptions implying that secular crimes also existed in ancient Japan.
"Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters) and "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan) include descriptions implying that secular crimes also existed in ancient Japan.

sen.j: 折口信夫は、天つ罪は元は「雨障（あまつつみ）」で、梅雨の時期に農民が忌み蘢ることを指していたという説を唱えている。
sen.e: If one follows Shinobu ORIKUCHI's theory, originally amatsu tsumi was written as 雨障, implying how during the rainy season, farmers stayed indoors and were repentant of their misdeeds.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処語源の説明のため漢字を残しました。
sen.e: If one follows Shinobu ORIKUCHI's theory, originally amatsu tsumi was written as 雨障, implied how during the rainy season, farmers stayed indoors and were repentant of their misdeeds.
If one follows Shinobu ORIKUCHI's theory, originally amatsu tsumi was written as 雨障, implied how during the rainy season, farmers stayed indoors and were repentant of their misdeeds.

sen.j: それが「天つ罪」とされ、日本神話におけるスサノオ命が高天原で犯した行為（岩戸隠れを参照）と解釈されるに至った。
sen.e: Gradually the characters 天つ罪 came to be used for amatsu tsumi, implying SUSANO no Mikoto's various misdeeds in Takamanohara, the Plain of High Heaven (see the section of "Amatogakure") in Japanese Mythology.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Gradually the characters 天つ罪 came to be used for amatsu tsumi, implying SUSANO no Mikoto's various misdeeds in Takamanohara, the Plain of High Heaven (see the section of "Amatogakure") in Japanese Mythology.

Gradually the characters 天つ罪 came to be used for amatsu tsumi, implying SUSANO no Mikoto's various misdeeds in Takamanohara, the Plain of High Heaven (see the section of "Iwatogakure") in Japanese Mythology.

sen.j: それに対応するものとして「国つ罪」が作られたという。
sen.e: In response to this interpretation, eventually kunitsu tsumi came to be perceived as the complementary opposite of amatsu tsumi.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In response to this interpretation, eventually kunitsu tsumi came to be perceived as the complementary opposite of amatsu tsumi.

sen.j: 大祓詞による天つ罪・国つ罪は以下のものである。
sen.e: Amatsu tsumi and Kunitsu tsumi described in oharae no kotoba include the followings.
Amatsu tsumi and Kunitsu tsumi described in oharae no kotoba include the followings.

sen.j: なお、大祓詞には罪の名前が書かれているだけで、特に国つ罪についてそれが何を意味するかについては諸説がある。
sen.e: Note that oharae no kotoba only listed the name of the crimes: there are various theories about what each crime means, especially those of Kunitsu tsumi.
Note that oharae no kotoba only listed the name of the crimes: there are various theories about what each crime means, especially those of Kunitsu tsumi.
Note that oharae no kotoba only listed the name of the crimes: there are various theories about what each crime means, especially those of Kunitsu tsumi.

sen.j: 『古事記』や『日本書紀』に記すスサノオ命が高天原で犯した行為に由来するとされる。
sen.e: It is said that Amatsu tsumi originates in the crimes committed by Susanoo no Mikoto in Takamanohara described in "Kojiki" and "Nihonshoki".
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: It is said that Amatsu tsumi originates in the crimes committed by Susanoo no Mikoto in Takamanohara described in "Kojiki" and "Nihonshoki".
It is said that Amatsu tsumi originates in the crimes committed by Susanoo no Mikoto in Takamanohara described in "Kojiki" and "Nihonshoki."

sen.j: 全て農耕を防害する人為的な行為であることから、クニ成立以前の共同体社会以来の犯罪であろうとされる。
sen.e: Because all of these crimes are acts to do harm to the agriculture caused by a man, these crimes are considered to exist since the emergence of communities before the establishment of the nation.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Because all of these crimes are acts to do harm to the agriculture caused by a man, these crimes are considered to exist since the emergence of communities before the establishment of the nation.
Because all of these crimes are acts to do harm to the agriculture caused by a man, these crimes are considered to exist since the emergence of communities before the establishment of the nation.

sen.j: 畔放（あはなち）
sen.e: Ahanachi
Ahanachi
Ahanachi

sen.j: -田に張っている水を、畔を壊すことで流出させ、水田灌漑を妨害することとされる。
sen.e: This is a crime to interrupt the rice field irrigation by breaking down the ridges between rice paddies and flowing the water out of the paddies.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: This is a crime where rice field irrigation is interrupted by breaking down the ridges between rice paddies and flowing the water out of the paddies.
This is a crime where rice field irrigation is interrupted by breaking down the ridges between rice paddies and flowing the water out of the paddies.

sen.j: 『古事記』・『日本書紀』にスサノオ命が高天原において天照大神の田に対してこれを行ったと記している
sen.e: "Kojiki" and "Nihonshoki" describe that Susanoo no Mikoto committed this crime against the rice field of Amaterasu Omikami (the Sun Goddess) in Takamanohara.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: "Kojiki" and "Nihonshoki" describe that Susanoo no Mikoto committed this crime against the rice field of Amaterasu Omikami (the Sun Goddess) in Takamanohara.

sen.j: 溝埋（みぞうめ）
sen.e: Mizoume
Mizoume
Mizoume

sen.j: -田に水を引くために設けた溝を埋めることで水を引けないようにする灌漑妨害で、これも『古事記』・『日本書紀』に記述がある
sen.e: This is a crime to interrupt the irrigation by filling in the irrigation ditches to prevent the water from being drawn, described in "Kojiki" and "Nihonshoki."

sen.e: This is a crime where irrigation is interrupted by filling in the irrigation ditches to prevent the water from being drawn, described in "Kojiki" and "Nihonshoki."

sen.j: 樋放（ひはなち）
sen.e: Hihanachi
Hihanachi
Hihanachi

sen.j: - 田に水を引くために設けた管を壊すことで水を引けないようにする灌漑妨害で、『日本書紀』に記述がある
sen.e: This is a crime to interrupt the irrigation by destroying the irrigation pipe to prevent the water from being drawn, described in "Nihonshoki."
This is a crime where irrigation is interrupted by destroying the irrigation pipe to prevent the water from being drawn, described in "Nihonshoki."

sen.j: 頻播（しきまき）
sen.e: Shikimaki
Shikimaki
Shikimaki

sen.j: - 他の人が種を蒔いた所に重ねて種を蒔いて作物の生長を妨げること（種を蒔く事で耕作権を奪うこととする説もある）で、『日本書紀』に記される
sen.e: This is a crime to sow the field where other people have already sown the seeds to hinder the development of crops (or to usurp the others of the cultivation right, some theory states), described in "Nihonshoki."

This is a crime where a field is sowed where other people have already sown seeds to hinder the development of crops (or to usurp the others of the cultivation right, some theory states), described in "Nihonshoki."

This is a crime where a field is sowed where other people have already sown seeds to hinder the development of crops (or to usurp the others of the cultivation right, some theory states), described in "Nihonshoki."

sen.j: 串刺（くしさし）
sen.e: Kushisashi
Kushisashi
Kushisashi

sen.j: - 『日本書紀』には、その起源をスサノオ命が高天原において天照大神の田を妬んでこれを行ったと記している。
sen.e: It is described in "Nihonshoki" that Susanoo no Mikoto committed this crime due to his envy of the rice field of Amaterasu Omikami in Takamanohara.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: It is described in "Nihonshoki" that Susanoo no Mikoto committed this crime due to his envy of the rice field of Amaterasu Omikami in Takamanohara.
It is described in "Nihonshoki" that Susanoo no Mikoto committed this crime due to his envy of the rice field of Amaterasu Omikami in Takamanohara.

sen.j: その目的は収穫時に他人の田畑に自分の土地であることを示す杭を立てて横領すること、とする。
sen.e: One theory states that the purpose of this crime is to usurp other people's fields by setting up stakes at harvest time.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: One theory states that the purpose of this crime is to usurp other people's fields by setting up stakes at harvest time.
One theory states that the purpose of this crime is to usurp other people's fields by setting up stakes at harvest time.

sen.j: 他に、他人の田畑に呪いを込めた串を刺すことでその所有者に害を及ぼす（または近寄れないようにした上で横領する）という呪詛説、田の中に多くの串を隠し立てて所有者の足を傷つける傷害説、家畜に串を刺して殺す家畜殺傷説の3説がある
sen.e: There are three other theories: a curse theory that this crime hurts the landowner by piercing a cursed skewer in the fields (or preventing the owner from approaching the field and usurp it); an injury theory that this crime hurts the landowner's legs by secretly setting up many skewers in the field; and a livestock slaughter theory that this crime kills livestock by piercing them with skewers.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: There are three other theories: a theory that this crime is a curse that hurts the landowner by piercing a cursed skewer in the fields (or preventing the owner from approaching the field and usurp it); a theory that this crime hurts the landowner's legs by secretly setting up many skewers in the field; and a theory that says this crime kills livestock by piercing them with skewers.

There are three other theories: a theory that this crime is a curse that hurts the landowner by piercing a cursed skewer in the fields (or preventing the owner from approaching the field and usurp it); a theory that this crime hurts the landowner's legs by secretly setting up many skewers in the field; and a theory that says this crime kills livestock by piercing them with skewers.

sen.j: 生剥（いきはぎ）
sen.e: Ikihagi
Ikihagi
Ikihagi

sen.j: - 馬の皮を生きながら剥ぐこととされ、『日本書紀』にスサノオ命が天照大神が神に献上する服を織っている殿内に天斑駒（あまのふちこま）を生剥にして投げ入れたとその起源を記している。
sen.e: This is a crime of skinning horses alive, originated in the description in "Nihonshoki" that Susanoo no Mikoto skinned Ama no fuchigoma Horse alive and threw it into the palace where Amaterasu Omikami was weaving the cloth to present to the God.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: This is a crime where horses are skinned alive, and originated in the description in "Nihonshoki" where Susanoo no Mikoto skinned Ama no fuchigoma Horse alive and threw it into the palace where Amaterasu Omikami was weaving the cloth to present to the God.

This is a crime where horses are skinned alive, and originated in the description in "Nihonshoki" where Susanoo no Mikoto skinned Ama no fuchigoma Horse alive and threw it into the palace where Amaterasu Omikami was weaving the cloth to present to the God.

sen.j: このことから、神事（ないしはその準備）の神聖性を侵犯するものとされるが、本来は単に家畜の皮を剥いで殺傷することとの説もある
sen.e: Based on this description, one theory states that this crime violates the sacredness of a divine service (or the preparation for the service); another theory states, on the other hand, that it only refers to skinning and slaughtering the livestock.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Based on this description, one theory states that this crime violates the sacredness of a divine service (or the preparation for the service); another theory states, on the other hand, that it only refers to skinning and slaughtering the livestock.

Based on this description, one theory states that this crime violates the sacredness of a divine service (or the preparation for the service); another theory states, on the other hand, that it only refers to skinning and slaughtering the livestock.

sen.j: 逆剥（さかはぎ）
sen.e: Sakahagi
Sakahagi
Sakahagi

sen.j: - 馬の皮を尻の方から剥ぐこととされ、『古事記』『日本書紀』に生剥と同じ起源を記していることから、これも神事の神聖性を侵犯するものとされる。
sen.e: This is a crime of skinning a horse backward from rear to front, and due to the same origin as Ikihagi described in "Kojiki" and "Nihonshoki," this is also regarded as the violation against the sacredness of a divine service.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: This is a crime where a horse is skinned backward from rear to front, and due to the same origin as Ikihagi described in "Kojiki" and "Nihonshoki," this is also regarded as the violation against the sacredness of a divine service.

This is a crime where a horse is skinned backward from rear to front, and due to the same origin as Ikihagi described in "Kojiki" and "Nihonshoki," this is also regarded as the violation against the sacredness of a divine service.

sen.j: が、本来は単に家畜を殺傷することとの説があるのも同様である。
sen.e: It is also the same as Ikihagi that it has another theory stating that it only refers to skinning and slaughtering the livestock.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: It is also the same as Ikihagi that it has another theory stating that it only refers to skinning and slaughtering the livestock.
It is also the same as Ikihagi that it has another theory stating that it only refers to skinning and slaughtering the livestock.

sen.j: 糞戸（くそへ）
sen.e: Kusohe
Kusohe
Kusohe

sen.j: - 『古事記』『日本書紀』にはスサノオ命が高天原において天照大神が大嘗祭（または新嘗祭）を斎行する神殿に脱糞したのが起源であると記している。
sen.e: "Kojiki" and "Nihonshoki" describe the origin of this crime that Susanoo no Mikoto defecated at the shrine in Takamanohara where Amaterasu Omikami performed Daijosai (first ceremonial offering of rice by newly-enthroned Emperor) or Niinamesai festival (ceremonial offering by the Emperor of newly-harvested rice to the deities).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: "Kojiki" and "Nihonshoki" describe the origin of this crime as being where Susanoo no Mikoto defecated at the shrine in Takamanohara where Amaterasu Omikami performed Daijosai (first ceremonial offering of rice by newly-enthroned Emperor) or Niinamesai festival (ceremonial offering by the Emperor of newly-harvested rice to the deities).

"Kojiki" and "Nihonshoki" describe the origin of this crime as being where Susanoo no Mikoto defecated at the shrine in Takamanohara where Amaterasu Omikami performed Daijosai (first ceremonial offering of rice by newly-enthroned Emperor) or Niinamesai festival (ceremonial offering by the Emperor of newly-harvested rice to the deities).

sen.j: このことから、これも神事に際して祭場を糞などの汚物で汚すこととされる。
sen.e: Based on this description, one theory states that this crime desecrates the ceremonial place for a divine service with filthy matters like excrements.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Based on this description, one theory states that this crime desecrates the ceremonial place for a divine service with filthy matters like excrements.
Based on this description, one theory states that this crime desecrates the ceremonial place for a divine service with filthy matters like excrements.

sen.j: また「くそと」と読み、「と」は祝詞（のりと）の「と」と同じく呪的行為を指すとして、本来は肥料としての糞尿に呪いをかけて作物に害を与える行為であるとの説もある
sen.e: Another theory states, on the other hand, that it should be read as "kusoto," in which "to," as in "norito," refers to a magical act, and kusoto is an act to pollute the crops by cursing the manure.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Another theory states, on the other hand, that it should be read as "kusoto," in which "to," as in "norito," refers to a magical act, and kusoto is an act to pollute the crops by cursing the manure.
Another theory states, on the other hand, that it should be read as "kusoto," in which "to," as in "norito," refers to a magical act, and kusoto is an act to pollute the crops by cursing the manure.

sen.j: 国つ罪は病気・災害を含み、現在の観念では「罪」に当たらないものもある点に特徴がある。
sen.e: Crimes described as Kunitsu tsumi include diseases and disasters that are not considered as "crime" in today's notion, which is a distinctive characteristic of Kunitsu tsumi.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Crimes described as Kunitsu tsumi include diseases and disasters that are not considered to be "crimes" in today's notion, which is a distinctive characteristic of Kunitsu tsumi.
Crimes described as Kunitsu tsumi include diseases and disasters that are not considered to be "crimes" in today's notion, which is a distinctive characteristic of Kunitsu tsumi.

sen.j: 一説に天変地異を人が罪を犯したことによって起こる現象と把え、人間が疵を負ったり疾患を被る（またこれによって死に至る）事や不適切な性的関係を結ぶ事によって、その人物の体から穢れが発生し、ひいては天変地異を引き起こす事になるためであると説明する。
sen.e: One theory explains that cataclysmic events are caused by human being committing crimes; by being injured or diseased (or die as a result), or having inappropriate sexual relationships, human body generates impurity and causes cataclysmic events as a result.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: One theory explains that cataclysmic events are caused by human being committing crimes; by being injured or diseased (or die as a result), or having inappropriate sexual relationships, human body generates impurity and causes cataclysmic events as a result.

One theory explains that cataclysmic events are caused by human being committing crimes; by being injured or diseased (or die as a result), or having inappropriate sexual relationships, human body generates impurity and causes cataclysmic events as a result.

sen.j: またその中のいくつかには、天武天皇朝における薬師如来信仰がその背景にあったと指摘されている。
sen.e: It is pointed out that some of Kunitsu tsumi were based on the belief in Yakushi Nyorai (the Healing Buddha) in the Emperor Tenmu's era.
It is pointed out that some of Kunitsu tsumi were based on the belief in Yakushi Nyorai (the Healing Buddha) in the Emperor Tenmu's era.
It is pointed out that some of Kunitsu tsumi were based on the belief in Yakushi Nyorai (the Healing Buddha) in the Emperor Tenmu's era.

sen.j: すなわち、天武天皇朝に薬師信仰が存したことは『日本書紀』に記載を見る
sen.e: The description of "Nihonshoki" proves that the faith in Yakushi existed in the era of Emperor Tenmu.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The description of "Nihonshoki" proves that the faith in Yakushi existed in the era of Emperor Tenmu.
The description of "Nihonshoki" proves that the faith in Yakushi existed in the era of Emperor Tenmu.
sen.cmt: スペース削除しました、

sen.j: 薬師信仰の一つには病気や災害を取り除くといった現世利益的な目的があり、そのために『薬師如来本願功徳経』（『薬師経』）の語句から採用されたものもあるのではないかとの指摘である。
sen.e: It is pointed out that one of the purposes of having the faith in Yakushi was to receive the worldly benefit such as removing a disease or disaster, thus some of Kunitsu tsumi must have derived from the text of "Yakushi Nyorai hongan kudokukyo" (Yakushikyo Sutra).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処原文には「薬師如来薬師経」とありましたが、Web上では「薬師如来本願功徳経」でしたので修正しました。
sen.e: It is pointed out that one of the purposes of having the faith in Yakushi was to receive the worldly benefit such as removing a disease or disaster, thus some of Kunitsu tsumi must have derived from the text of "Yakushi Nyorai hongan kudokukyo" (Yakushikyo Sutra).

It is pointed out that one of the purposes of having the faith in Yakushi was to receive the worldly benefit such as removing a disease or disaster, thus some of Kunitsu tsumi must have derived from the text of "Yakushi Nyorai hongan kudokukyo" (Yakushikyo Sutra).

sen.j: 生膚断（いきはだたち）
sen.e: Ikihadadachi
Ikihadadachi
Ikihadadachi

sen.j: - 生きている人の肌に傷をつけることで、所謂傷害罪に相当する
sen.e: This is a crime of hurting a living person's skin, equivalent to a charge of bodily injury.
This is a crime of hurting a living person's skin, equivalent to a charge of bodily injury.
This is a crime of hurting a living person's skin, equivalent to a charge of bodily injury.

sen.j: 死膚断（しにはだたち）
sen.e: Shinihadadachi
Shinihadadachi
Shinihadadachi

sen.j: - 直接的解釈では、死んだ人の肌に傷をつけることで、現在の死体損壊罪に相当する。
sen.e: A direct interpretation states that Shinihadadachi is a crime of hurting a dead body's skin, equivalent to a charge of damage to corpse.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: A direct interpretation states that Shinihadadachi is a crime of hurting a dead body's skin, equivalent to a charge of vandalising a corpse.
A direct interpretation states that Shinihadadachi is a crime of hurting a dead body's skin, equivalent to a charge of vandalizing a corpse.

sen.j: その目的は何らかの呪的行為にあるとされるが、また前項の生膚断が肌を傷つけられた被害者がまだ生存しているのに対し、被害者を傷つけて死に至らしめる、所謂傷害致死罪に相当するとの説もある
sen.e: The purpose of this crime is said to be an act of curse; however, in another theory, while the victim of Ikihadadachi described in the previous section was still alive when his/her skin was hurt, the victim of shinihadadachi was injured to death, therefore it is equivalent to a charge of injury resulting in death.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The purpose of this crime is said to be enact a curse; however, in another theory, while the victim of Ikihadadachi described in the previous section was still alive when his/her skin was hurt, the victim of shinihadadachi was injured to death, therefore it is equivalent to a charge of injury resulting in death.

The purpose of this crime is said to be enact a curse; however, in another theory, while the victim of Ikihadadachi described in the previous section was still alive when his/her skin was hurt, the victim of shinihadadachi was injured to death, therefore it is equivalent to a charge of injury resulting in death.

sen.j: 白人（しらひと）
sen.e: Shirahito
Shirahito
Shirahito

sen.j: - 肌の色が白くなる病気で、「白癩（びゃくらい・しらはたけ）」とも呼ばれ、所謂ハンセン病の1種とされる。
sen.e: Shirahito refers to a disease of pale skin, also called Byakurai or Shirahatake, and it is said to be a kind of leprosy.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Shirahito refers to a disease of pale skin, also called Byakurai or Shirahatake, and it is said to be a kind of leprosy.
Shirahito refers to a disease of pale skin, also called Byakurai or Shirahatake, and it is said to be a kind of leprosy.

sen.j: これが国津罪の一として現れるについては、『薬師経』に薬師如来が菩薩行を行った時に12の大願を起こし、その6番目で人間の様々な病患も薬師如来の名前を聞けば全て取り除かれるであろうと説いた。
sen.e: One theory states that the reason of counting this disease as one of Kunitsu tsumi is found in "Yakushikyo Sutra;" when Yakushi Nyorai performed Bosatsu gyo, it made twelve great vows and the sixth vow declared that every human disease would be healed by hearing the name of Yakushi Nyorai.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: One theory states that the reason of counting this disease as one of Kunitsu tsumi is found in "Yakushikyo Sutra;" when Yakushi Nyorai performed Bosatsu gyo, it made twelve great vows and the sixth vow declared that every human disease would be healed by hearing the name of Yakushi Nyorai.

One theory states that the reason of counting this disease as one of Kunitsu tsumi is found in "Yakushikyo Sutra;" when Yakushi Nyorai performed Bosatsu gyo, it made twelve great vows and the sixth vow declared that every human disease would be healed by hearing the name of Yakushi Nyorai.

sen.j: その病患の具体例を「其身下劣、諸根不具、醜陋頑愚、聾盲跋躄、身攣背傴、白癩癲狂、」と挙げており、ここに挙げられた「白癩」が相当するとの説がある
sen.e: Examples of disease include "people born with deformities, ugly, stubborn, idiot, blind, deaf, disabled hands or legs; hunchbacked, or pale skin," and the last refers to Shirahito.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Examples of disease include "people born with deformities, ugly, stubborn, idiot, blind, deaf, disabled hands or legs; hunchbacked, or pale skin," and the last refers to Shirahito.
Examples of disease include 'people born with deformities, ugly, stubborn, idiot, blind, deaf, disabled hands or legs; hunchbacked, or pale skin,' and the last refers to Shirahito.
sen.cmt: 原文の「」に合せて"を'に訂正しました。

sen.j: 胡久美（こくみ）
sen.e: Kokumi
Kokumi
Kokumi

sen.j: - 背中に大きな瘤ができること（所謂せむし）。
sen.e: Kokumi refers to a condition in which a person develops a big lump, on the back, or so-called hunchback.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Kokumi refers to a condition in which a person develops a big lump, on the back, or so-called hunchback.
Kokumi refers to a condition in which a person develops a big lump, on the back, or so-called hunchback.

sen.j: 上記『薬師経』の「身攣背傴」に由来するとの説がある
sen.e: One theory states that it came from the description of "Yakushikyo sutra" as described above.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: One theory states that it came from the description of "Yakushikyo sutra" as described above.
One theory states that it came from the description of "Yakushikyo sutra" as described above.

sen.j: 己（おの）が母犯せる罪
sen.e: A charge of raping his own mother
A charge of raping his own mother
A charge of raping his own mother

sen.j: - 実母との相姦（近親相姦）
sen.e: - An incest with his own mother
- Incest with his own mother
Incest with his own mother
sen.cmt: ハイフン削除しました。

sen.j: 己が子犯せる罪
sen.e: A charge of raping his own child
A charge of raping his own child
A charge of raping his own child

sen.j: - 実子との相姦
sen.e: - An incest with his own child
- Incest with his own child
Incest with his own child
sen.cmt: ハイフン削除しました。

sen.j: 母と子と犯せる罪
sen.e: A charge of raping a mother and its child
A charge of raping a mother and its child
A charge of raping a mother and its child

sen.j: - ある女と性交し、その後その娘と相姦すること
sen.e: - Having a sexual intercourse with a woman and then with her daughter
- Having a sexual intercourse with a woman and then with her daughter
Having a sexual intercourse with a woman and then with her daughter
sen.cmt: ハイフン削除しました。

sen.j: 子と母と犯せる罪
sen.e: A charge of raping a child and its mother
A charge of raping a child and its mother
A charge of raping a child and its mother

sen.j: - ある女と性交し、その後その母と相姦すること（以上4罪は『古事記』仲哀天皇段に「上通下通婚（おやこたわけ）」として総括されており、修辞技法として分化されているだけで、意味上の相違はないとの説もある）
sen.e: - Having a sexual intercourse with a woman and then with her mother (the four charges described above are summarized as "Oyakotawake" in the section of Emperor Chuai in "Kojiki," thus there is a theory stating that these are divided only for the sake of rhetoric and thus have no difference in the meaning).

- Having a sexual intercourse with a woman and then with her mother (the four charges described above are summarized as "Oyakotawake" in the section of Emperor Chuai in "Kojiki," thus there is a theory stating that these are divided only for the sake of rhetoric and thus have no difference in the meaning).

Having a sexual intercourse with a woman and then with her mother (the four charges described above are summarized as 'Oyakotawake' in the section of Emperor Chuai in "Kojiki," thus there is a theory stating that these are divided only for the sake of rhetoric and thus have no difference in the meaning).
sen.cmt: ハイフン削除しました。原文の「」に合せて"を'に訂正しました。

sen.j: 畜犯せる罪
sen.e: A charge of raping animals
A charge of raping animals
A charge of raping animals

sen.j: - 獣姦のことで、『古事記』仲哀天皇段には「馬婚（うまたわけ）」、「牛婚（うしたわけ）」、「鶏婚（とりたわけ）」、「犬婚（いぬたわけ）」と細分化されている
sen.e: - It refers to bestiality and it is categorized in the section of Emperor Chuai in "Kojiki" into "Umatawake" (bestiality with horse), "Toritawake" (bestiality with chicken), and "Inutawake" (bestiality with dogs).

- It refers to bestiality and it is categorized in the section of Emperor Chuai in "Kojiki" into "Umatawake" (bestiality with horse), "Toritawake" (bestiality with chicken), and "Inutawake" (bestiality with dogs).

It refers to bestiality and it is categorized in the section of Emperor Chuai in "Kojiki" into 'Umatawake' (bestiality with horse), 'Toritawake' (bestiality with chicken), and 'Inutawake' (bestiality with dogs).
sen.cmt: ハイフン削除しました。余分なスペースを削除しました。原文の「」に合せて"を'に訂正しました。

sen.j: 昆虫（はうむし）の災
sen.e: Woes by crawling insects
Woes by crawling insects
Woes by crawling insects

sen.j: - 地面を這う昆虫（毒蛇やムカデ、サソリなど）による災難である。
sen.e: This refers to calamities caused by crawling insects (such as poisonous snakes, centipedes, and scorpions).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: This refers to calamities caused by crawling insects (such as poisonous snakes, centipedes, and scorpions).
This refers to calamities caused by crawling insects (such as poisonous snakes, centipedes, and scorpions).

sen.j: 『薬師経』に「悪象・師子・虎狼・熊羆・毒蛇・悪蝎・蜈蚣・蚰蜒、如是等怖」も薬師如来に祈れば取り除かれるであろうと説いている。
sen.e: In "Yakushikyo Sutra," there is a description that "evil elephants, lions, tigers, wolves, bears, poisonous snakes, scorpions, centipedes, mosquitoes, gnats, or other frightful things" would be cleared by praying for Yakushi Nyorai.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In "Yakushikyo Sutra," there is a description that "evil elephants, lions, tigers, wolves, bears, poisonous snakes, scorpions, centipedes, mosquitoes, gnats, or other frightful things" would be cleared by praying for Yakushi Nyorai.

In "Yakushikyo Sutra," there is a description that 'evil elephants, lions, tigers, wolves, bears, poisonous snakes, scorpions, centipedes, mosquitoes, gnats, or other frightful things' would be cleared by praying for Yakushi Nyorai.
sen.cmt: 原文の「」に合せて"を'に訂正しました。

sen.j: このため、ここに挙げられた「毒蛇」以下が相当するとの説もある。
sen.e: One theory states, therefore, that "crawling insects" refers to those listed following "poisonous snakes" in this description.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: One theory states, therefore, that "crawling insects" refers to those listed following "poisonous snakes" in this description.
One theory states, therefore, that 'crawling insects' refers to those listed following 'poisonous snakes' in this description.
sen.cmt: 原文の「」に合せて"を'に訂正しました。

sen.j: 高つ神の災
sen.e: Woes by Takatsu Kami
Woes by Takatsu Kami
Woes by Takatsu Kami

sen.j: - 落雷などの天災とされる。
sen.e: It is regarded as natural disasters such as lightning damage.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: It is regarded as natural disasters such as lightning damage.
It is regarded as natural disasters such as lightning damage.

sen.j: しかし、『薬師経』の影響を勘案して、『薬師経』にある「夜叉・羅刹・毘舎闍等、諸悪鬼神」を踏まえた広い意味での悪神による災害とする説もある
sen.e: Another theory, by taking the influence of "Yakushikyo Sutra" into consideration, states that this refers to disasters by unrighteous divine spirits in a broad sense, as described in the Sutra: "yaksha, rakshasa, bishaja, and other evil fierce gods."
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Another theory, by taking the influence of "Yakushikyo Sutra" into consideration, states that this refers to disasters by unrighteous divine spirits in a broad sense, as described in the Sutra: "yaksha, rakshasa, bishaja, and other evil fierce gods."

Another theory, by taking the influence of "Yakushikyo Sutra" into consideration, states that this refers to disasters by unrighteous divine spirits in a broad sense, as described in the Sutra: 'yaksha, rakshasa, bishaja, and other evil fierce gods.'
sen.cmt: 原文の「」に合せて"を'に訂正しました。

sen.j: 高つ鳥の災
sen.e: Woes by Takatsu Tori
Woes by Takatsu Tori
Woes by Takatsu Tori

sen.j: - 大殿祭（おおとのほがい）の祝詞には「飛ぶ鳥の災」とあり、猛禽類による家屋損傷などの災難とされる。
sen.e: "Woes by flying birds" is found in Norito of Otonohogai, and thus it is considered to refer to damages to buildings and other mishaps caused by raptorial birds.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: "Woes by flying birds" is found in Norito of Otonohogai, and thus it is considered to refer to damages to buildings and other mishaps caused by raptorial birds.
"Woes by flying birds" is found in Norito of Otonohogai, and thus it is considered to refer to damages to buildings and other mishaps caused by raptorial birds.

sen.j: これも『薬師経』に「怪鳥来集」とあるのが基になったものとの説がある
sen.e: This also has another theory stating that this is based on the description of "attacks by monstrous birds" in "Yakushikyo Sutra."
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: This also has another theory stating that this is based on the description of "attacks by monstrous birds" in "Yakushikyo Sutra."
This also has another theory stating that this is based on the description of 'attacks by monstrous birds' in "Yakushikyo Sutra."
sen.cmt: 原文の「」に合せて"を'に訂正しました。

sen.j: 畜仆し（けものたおし）、蠱物（まじもの）する罪
sen.e: Kemonotaoshi, a crime of doing Majimono
Kemonotaoshi, a crime of doing Majimono
Kemonotaoshi, a crime of doing Majimono

sen.j: - 家畜を殺し、その屍体で他人を呪う蠱道（こどう）のことである。
sen.e: This refers to Kodo, a magic ritual to kill house stocks and place a curse on others using the carcasses.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: This refers to Kodo, a magic ritual to kill house stocks and place a curse on others using the carcasses.
This refers to Kodo, a magic ritual to kill house stocks and place a curse on others using the carcasses.

sen.j: これも『薬師経』に薬師如来の力で人々の悪行が全て消滅するであろうと説いている中の、「告林神・樹神・山神・塚神・種々別神、殺諸畜生、取其血肉、祭祀一切夜叉羅刹食血肉者、書怨人字、并作其形、成就種々毒害呪術・厭魅蠱道・起屍鬼呪、欲断彼命、及壊其身」の句、特に「殺諸畜生」以下が基になったものとの説もある
sen.e: Here, too, "Yakushikyo Sutra" has a description in the section where every evil act done by people will be expiated by the power of Yakushi Nyorai, "They pray to the spirits of the mountain forests, trees, and graves. They kill living beings in order to make sacrifices of blood and flesh to the yaksha and rakshasa ghosts. They write down the names of their enemies and make images of them, and then they hex those names and images with evil mantras. They summon paralysis ghosts, cast hexes, or command corpse-raising ghosts to kill or injure their enemies" and the section following "They kill living beings" in particular.'
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Here, too, "Yakushikyo Sutra" has a description in the section where every evil act done by people will be expiated by the power of Yakushi Nyorai, "They pray to the spirits of the mountain forests, trees, and graves. They kill living beings in order to make sacrifices of blood and flesh to the yaksha and rakshasa ghosts. They write down the names of their enemies and make images of them, and then they hex those names and images with evil mantras. They summon paralysis ghosts, cast hexes, or command corpse-raising ghosts to kill or injure their enemies" and the section following "They kill living beings" in particular.'

Here, too, "Yakushikyo Sutra" has a description in the section where every evil act done by people will be expiated by the power of Yakushi Nyorai, 'They pray to the spirits of the mountain forests, trees, and graves. They kill living beings in order to make sacrifices of blood and flesh to the yaksha and rakshasa ghosts. They write down the names of their enemies and make images of them, and then they hex those names and images with evil mantras. They summon paralysis ghosts, cast hexes, or command corpse-raising ghosts to kill or injure their enemies' and the section following 'They kill living beings' in particular.
sen.cmt: 原文の「」に合せて"を'に訂正しました。

sen.j: なお、『日本書紀』神宮皇后摂政元年2月の条にある「阿豆那比（あずない）の罪」（2社の神官を一緒に埋葬すること）もこれに准じるものである。
sen.e: Note that "Azunai no tsumi" (a crime of burying priests of two shrines together) described in the article of February of the first year of Sessho (regent) of Empress Jingu in "Nihon Shoki" can also be included to these crimes.

Note that "Azunai no tsumi" (a crime of burying priests of two shrines together) described in the article of February of the first year of Sessho (regent) of Empress Jingu in "Nihon Shoki" can also be included to these crimes.

Note that 'Azunai no tsumi' (a crime of burying priests of two shrines together) described in the article of February of the first year of Sessho (regent) of Empress Jingu in "Nihon Shoki" can also be included to these crimes.

sen.j: また、『皇太神宮儀式帳』には川入（川に入って溺死すること）・火焼（火によって焼死する事）を国つ罪に追加している。
sen.e: Moreover, "Kotai Jingu Gishikicho" adds Kawairi (die by drowning in a river) and Hiyaki (burnt by fire to death) to Kunitsu tsumi crimes.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処「川入」と「火焼」は読み方が不明です。Kawairi 、Hiyakiとしてあります。
sen.e: Moreover, "Kotai Jingu Gishikicho" adds Kawairi (die by drowning in a river) and Hiyaki (burnt by fire to death) to Kunitsu tsumi crimes.
Moreover, "Kotai Jingu Gishikicho" adds Kawairi (die by drowning in a river) and Hiyaki (burnt by fire to death) to Kunitsu tsumi crimes.

sen.j: この2項も『薬師経』の9つの横死を述べる箇所に、第4は火に焼かれること、第5は水に溺れることとあり、薬師信仰との関連が指摘できる。
sen.e: Regarding these two cases, "Yakushikyo Sutra" has a section to describe nine kinds of untimely death, the fourth is to be burned to death and the fifth is to drown, so the relation to the brief in Yakushi Nyorai can be suggested.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Regarding these two cases, "Yakushikyo Sutra" has a section to describe nine kinds of untimely death, the fourth is to be burned to death and the fifth is to drown, so the relation to the brief in Yakushi Nyorai can be suggested.

Regarding these two cases, "Yakushikyo Sutra" has a section to describe nine kinds of untimely death, the fourth is to be burned to death and the fifth is to drown, so the relation to the brief in Yakushi Nyorai can be suggested.

sen.j: 神社本庁およびその配下の神社で用いられる大祓詞では、国つ罪に差別的な表現があるとして、天つ罪・国つ罪の罪名の部分はカットされている。
sen.e: In Oharae no kotoba used by Jinja Honcho (Association of Shinto Shrines) and its subordinate shrines, the names of crimes in Amatsu tsumi and Kunitsu tsumi have been omitted because Kunitsu tsumi include discriminatory expressions.

In Oharae no kotoba used by Jinja Honcho (Association of Shinto Shrines) and its subordinate shrines, the names of crimes in Amatsu tsumi and Kunitsu tsumi have been omitted because Kunitsu tsumi include discriminatory expressions.

In Oharae no kotoba used by Jinja Honcho (Association of Shinto Shrines) and its subordinate shrines, the names of crimes in Amatsu tsumi and Kunitsu tsumi have been omitted because Kunitsu tsumi include discriminatory expressions.

sen.j: すなわち、現在の大祓詞で「天つ罪 国つ罪 許許太久（ここだく）の罪出でむ」となっている部分は、本来は「天つ罪と 畦放 溝埋 樋放 頻蒔 串刺 生剥 逆剥 屎戸 許多の罪を天つ罪と法（の）り別（わ）けて 国つ罪と 生膚断 死膚断 白人 胡久美 おのが母犯せる罪 おのが子犯せる罪 母と子と犯せる罪 子と母と犯せる罪 畜犯せる罪 昆ふ虫の災 高つ神の災 高つ鳥の災 畜仆し蟲物する罪 許多の罪出でむ」である。
sen.e: Therefore, where Oharae no kotoba today reads "Amatsu tsumi Kunitsu tsumi and many other such crimes come forth," it originally read "Amatsu tsumi and ahanachi, mizoume, hihanachi, shikimaki, kushisashi, ikihagi, sakahagi, kusohe, and many other crimes; by declaring separately from Amatsu tsumi, Kunitsu tsumi and ikihadadachi; shinihadadachi; shirahito; kokumi; a charge of raping his own mother, raping his own child, raping a mother and its child, raping a child and its mother, raping animals; woes by crawling insects, takatsu kami, and takatsu tori; Kemonotaoshi, a crime of doing Majimono; and many other such crimes come forth."

Therefore, where Oharae no kotoba today reads "Amatsu tsumi Kunitsu tsumi and many other such crimes come forth," it originally read "Amatsu tsumi and ahanachi, mizoume, hihanachi, shikimaki, kushisashi, ikihagi, sakahagi, kusohe, and many other crimes; by declaring separately from Amatsu tsumi, Kunitsu tsumi and ikihadadachi; shinihadadachi; shirahito; kokumi; a charge of raping his own mother, raping his own child, raping a mother and its child, raping a child and its mother, raping animals; woes by crawling insects, takatsu kami, and takatsu tori; Kemonotaoshi, a crime of doing Majimono; and many other such crimes come forth."

Therefore, where Oharae no kotoba today reads 'Amatsu tsumi Kunitsu tsumi and many other such crimes come forth' it originally read 'Amatsu tsumi and ahanachi, mizoume, hihanachi, shikimaki, kushisashi, ikihagi, sakahagi, kusohe, and many other crimes; by declaring separately from Amatsu tsumi, Kunitsu tsumi and ikihadadachi; shinihadadachi; shirahito; kokumi; a charge of raping his own mother, raping his own child, raping a mother and its child, raping a child and its mother, raping animals; woes by crawling insects, takatsu kami, and takatsu tori; Kemonotaoshi, a crime of doing Majimono; and many other such crimes come forth.'
sen.cmt: "を'にj訂正しました。スペース削除。
